text.text: The musicians and artists who contributed to this project were Gordon and Kelly's friends, family, and favorites. There were also a few bands who had lost friends in similar circumstances, and wanted to further the mission of H.E.L.L. Some people chose to share their lyrics and messages to their late friends. You can see the reach of their friendship was far based on location of each artist. This Story Map highlights their submission along with other works and media not associated with this compilation--as their art is bigger than this album and that's how Gordon and Kelly would want it.

New York, NY
Song: Into Her Arms

Music & lyrics by Robert Fish/Rasaraja, Tim Cohen/Trivikrama and Michael Justian. Recorded October 2011 in Boston, MA and Portland, OR.  

“I met Kelly, and had a meaningful conversation with her in March of 2007. Less than two months later she was killed. This song is for her, and also for my sister Jacqui who was hit by a car and disappeared in June of 1987. Let it also be for everyone that goes through painful losses. Love and healing to you.” — Trivikrama dasa, January 2012

Into her arms… We walk through the fog, heads down, eyes fixed forward. We wish for relief yet we yearn for everything else. We walk for endless miles wishing we were anywhere else. Denying her cold embrace while walking straight into her arms. Into her arms. I’m finding it hard to breathe, can’t put a single thought  together because all I can feel is the feeling of nothing at all. What I wouldn’t give to see your smile just one more time and what I wouldn’t do to guide you away from the embrace. Into her arms. This road we walk is endless and the sounds won’t stop. My mind’s always moving, moving beyond me. Her cold embrace, her ashen face it rips right through me. I’ve lost you into her arms. We walk through the fog, heads down, eyes fixed forward. We wish for relief yet we yearn for  everything else. We walk for endless miles wishing we were anywhere else.  Denying her cold embrace while walking straight into her arms. Into her arms.

text.headline: Attica! Attica!
text.text:
Portland, OR
Song: You, The Music, and Me

Written by Aaron Scott. Aaron Scott  (vocals, accordion, acoustic guitar), Isaac Hayden (cello), Oscar Albis Rodriguez (bass, additional acoustic guitar.) Vocals and cello recorded by Davey Death Ray at DZL Sound in Portland, OR. Accordion and acoustic guitar recorded by Aaron Scott at The Siren in Portland, OR. Bass and additional acoustic guitar recorded by Oscar Albis Rodriguez at Home in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Mixed by Davey Death Ray at DZL Sound in Portland, OR.

“My friend Jake died last year in a skateboarding accident. He fell off his board, hit his head on gravel, and was brain-dead within hours. The swiftest  ambulance and the most skilled surgeon could not save him from the bleeding inside his skull. I was about to say that this song is for Jake, but that’s silly,  because Jake isn’t alive anymore. It’s just another of those impulses to  personify the dead so I can pretend that he isn’t really gone forever. But he is. So instead, let me say that this song is for us. It’s for those of us who still have life, and still have an opportunity to do something with it. So do something with it. Because that’s all we have, until we don’t.” — Aaron

Your hand is still warm but no tension is there. While I cling to it, slumped in this hospital chair. And I choke out some nonsense about how I’ll see you again. But I say these things to deny that I lack the courage to say goodbye. And I hum an old song we wrote when we were young while my jagged voice cracks and bends. And it’s you…The melody strays out of tune. But it’s you...just you, the music and me. Down the hall at the chapel they speak of a plan so mysterious that we  cannot understand. How can this non-explanation assuage any grief? Do they tell the orphans who survived inexplicable horrors of genocide that god has a design and he kept you in mind when your parents were shot in the street? I rather think that there’s no reason for this, and chaos decides when we cease to exist. But how can I say that to mothers who bury their sons? Instead, I choose not to speak, and put on my headphones so I can think. And it’s you…Your guitar’s distorted and blue. But it’s you…just you, the music and me. Friends, we gather together again. We’re fewer than last we met but moments of silence are somber, uptight. No, we mourn as loud as we can. So can I get an amen? Let’s start up the dirge and we’ll sing our last goodbye. Sing goodbye. Goodbye my old comrade, goodbye my dear friend. It shreds me that I’ll never see you again. But I’m proud to say we never sat around waiting to die. We were saved by spectacular sounds that moved us to make our paradise now. And we made the air shake because we wouldn’t wait to get the best out of life. This savior is not something you can see, it twists the intestines and chatters the teeth and it pulses the heart and it pours from our hands and our throats. I feel the band starting to play, I close my eyes, my skull resonates. And it’s you…your memory is vivid and true. Yes it’s you…just you, the music and me.

text.headline: Brian Marquis
text.text:
Los Angeles, CA
Song: '84 Rookie Card

Music and Lyrics by Brian Marquis. Brian Marquis (vocals/guitar.) Produced, Engineered & Mixed by Brad Delava. Recorded at 37' Productions, Rockland, MA.

Didn’t care for Jesus Christ, God or heaven above. He believed in something deeper. He believed in one love. His heart and mind. Strong and sharp. Stop on a dime. He belongs down here with us. Sometimes life gets caught up in the spokes. Like a 1984 rookie card. You could spend your whole life. Waiting to decide. Which road is best to take. Which one is mine. Better to be black and blue. From living life through and through. The wheels keep spinning ’round and ’round. “When forever comes crashing” in. Wings unbound, you start falling. The ground rushes for your head. Before it’s all said and done. We’ll always be missing one. He left us with just one request. Home is where the heart is. Even when it’s underground.

text.headline: Jason Anderson
text.text:
Manchester, NH
Song: Don't Give Up Just Yet

I can’t believe my glove was waiting for me on the steps to my apartment. And, in this way, I hear the universe sing: “See how things work out when you don’t think they will? Well, they will. They will. So don’t give up just yet. No, don’t give up just yet. Remember, remember. Don’t give up just yet. OK? Don’t give up just yet. Remember, remember. Don’t give up just yet.”

text.headline: Battle!
text.text:
Gainesville, FL
Song: Brick

Battle! was James (vocals), Riley (guitar), Jim (Drums) Evan (Bass) and Andrew (Guitar). The song Brick was recorded in 2009 at Fleafarm Studios in Allston, MA.

“We can’t express how much love and respect we have for Kelly Anne Wallace! She had such a huge impact on this band and who we are as people! She will forever be missed and its impossible to express that in words! I hope that everyone who hears this comp will at least be a little bit more careful when they’re out on the streets on a bike, skateboard, roller blades, whatever. The world is not a safe place, so do your best stay safe!” — B!

Piece by piece I’m falling apart. Standing in the empty circle, I’m praying you won’t find me here. I take each breath like a brick on my chest. I close my eyes tighter but the room just gets brighter. Blinding me, I just want to be left alone. Depression is a full time job and I need a day off. Or maybe a good memory that I could reflect back on. Nothing’s going to make me feel alright again. Day by day I try to keep myself inspired but living this way seems next to impossible. “What makes you think that I’m that strong. I wear these deep scars on my arms. They bleed when I want them to bleed. Your 2 cents I don’t need.” I’m not asking for your help. This is just something I can handle on my own. I don’t need any  direction from any of you. This is just something I’m handling on my own.

media.credit: A Wolf Among Lilacs - Medicated Kisses (Alanna's former band)

text.headline: Alanna
text.text:
Nashville, TN
Song: Surprise, You're Alive

Written by Alanna Quinn-Broadus. Produced  by Alanna Quinn-Broadus. Engineered by Jared Colby at Trapdoor Studios.

text.headline: Converge
text.text:
Boston, MA
Song: On My Shield

Jacob Bannon (vocals, lyrics, visuals), Kurt Ballou (guitar, backing vocals), Nate Newton (bass) and Ben Koller (drums). Produced, Engineered, and Mixed by Kurt Ballou at God City, summer 2010. Originally  self-released as a 7" single, summer of 2010.

text.headline: Form & File
text.text:
Allston, MA
Song: Mundane Pleasures

TJ Kelley III (Guitar, Vocals), Ryan Briggs (Guitar, Vocals), Rory Hamovit (Bass Guitar), and Tyson Luneau (Drums).  Recorded, mixed and mastered by Ryan Stack at Andrews Lane Recording Studio.  

When we lose someone it’s hard to feel in control. When we lose someone it feels so incomplete. How empty every little thing feels. It’s the mundane things that we’ll miss the most. Life is taken away, O how life is taken. It’s the times we stayed inside instead of going out and how sweet those hours could have been. Instead we’re left to regret. When we lose someone it’s hard to feel anything. It’s hard to understand, and to want. Want of those few minutes lost. O how things could have been. This song is for those we’ll never see again.

text.headline: Oscar Albis Rodriguez
text.text:
Brooklyn, NY
Song: My Dear Rachel

Written, performed, produced, engineered, and mixed by Oscar in April 2011 at home in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Mastered by Bill Henderson at Azimuth Mastering.

My dear Rachel you fell off your bike. You broke your hand and that’s just not right. ’Cause you’re the sickest guitar shredder that I know. That BMX rode the wrong way. You got stranded at Woodhull all fucking day. I couldn’t go so now I’m writing you this song. Why does the worst shit happen at the perfect time? Can’t we all be fine on our bikes? It’s not that we’re cursed but sometimes I wonder what I did wrong in a past life that I don’t believe in. My dear Rachel what do you need? Some vegan food or a book to read? A bottle of whiskey can work wonders to pass the time. Or maybe I can come over to hang, watch bad tv and make fun of bands. Or maybe I can finish your songs and you could finish mine. Why does the worst shit happen at the perfect time? Can’t we all be fine for just one night? It’s not that we’re cursed but sometimes I wonder what is going on with all these answers that I don’t believe in. Everyone falls down; it just matters how you pick it up, you know your friends send all this love. Yeah it takes some time; but soon you’ll be back on your bike and melting faces left and right. Why does the worst shit happen at the perfect time? Can’t we all be fine all our lives? It’s not that we’re cursed but sometimes I wonder why it takes so long to find something that I’ll believe in.

text.headline: Fly Upright Kite
text.text:
Boston, MA
Song: You Shine

Asad Rahman (vocals, guitar), Holland Dieringer  (violin, xylophone), Jarred Grant (drums) and Liam McCormack (bass, keys).  Recorded, Mixed, and Mastered by James Zaner at Blue Jay Studio, Carlisle, MA. Additional home recording by Asad Rahman. Music by Fly Upright Kite, Lyrics by Asad Rahman.

text.headline: Foxfires
text.text:
Worcester, MA
Song: Nostrum

Ryan Martin, Jesse Menard, Josh Smith,  Josh Lyford and Conor Hobbs. Recorded by Ian Van Opijnen at Echo Room Studios.

text.headline: The Faux
text.text:
Boston, MA
Song: Biology ≠ Destiny

Originally released by The Faux as part of the first demo. Ginn Norris (vocals/lyrics), Rob Yanes (drums), Jon Howard (guitar), Jaux Coelhaux (guitar), Donnie Shaw (bass guitar) and Kirsten Malone (keyboards/additional vocals.) Recorded in 2001 at New Alliance Studio in Boston and engineered by Kevin Mica.

In the fall of 2000, Jaux and Kirsten told me they were starting a new band and asked if I would play guitar until it was up and running. They were my room mates and I was a huge fan of their previous band, The Statue Factor. This project ended up being so fun and played a whole bunch of shows really fast. Ginn and I were actually in this band only a short time but got to open for some bands like Le Tigre, The Rapture, Tracy and the Plastics, The Goonies, and Glass Candy.

The original lineup fell apart in the Summer of 2001 but The Faux ended up playing another 3 years before Kirsten’s untimely death. In 2004 Kirsten was killed in a car accident at the bottom of the Lower Allston footbridge. This track is dedicated to the memory of Kirsten Malone a.k.a. Lady K, one of the coolest room mates I ever had and a great person to be in a band with. Kirsten was fire in this city; always bright, fast and unpredictable.

The 4 tracks we recorded with her and I on them mean a lot to me and were basically just passed out at shows on a CDR ten years ago. I am very psyched to have something I collaborated on with Kirsten be published. I hope H.E.L.L. and projects like it make helmets the norm for all bicyclists. So, thanks to Justin for doing this project. I’ve pretty much not mentioned The Faux being on this compilation so as to surprise the members from the line-up on this early and rare track, so this track goes out to Ginn, Donnie, Jaux, Rob, too. I love and miss those days and this band represents a lot of how I see my place in the Boston punk scene. — Jon Howard, 2011

text.headline: The First Annual
text.text:
Merrimack Valley, MA
Song: Like We Used To Do

The First Annual was Greg Kell,  Jeff Torrice, Zac Torrice, Steve Zuretti. Additional instrumentation and vocals  by Danielle Capalbo. Recorded, Mixed and Mastered by Mike Poorman at  Strangeways Recording Studio in Providence, R.I.

text.headline: Late Nite Wars
text.text:
Merrimack Valley, MA
Song: Bones

Original version on the 2011 release “Who’s Going To Miss You If You Go?” Erik Lipson (guitars), Aaron Bernard (Casio CZ-101) and Kevin Quinn (vocals). Engineered and Mixed by Aaron Bernard. Mastered by Ryan Stack at Format Audio in Haverhill, MA.

A decade to the day waiting at the gate. Overlooking your resting place. Watching people cross never taking time to stop. Reminds you of yourself. When you live so cold it chills you to the bone. And they walk in silence over you. No echoing eulogy. And they’ll stalk a phrase on every grave. And yours will say, only a name. Make sure you know who’s gonna miss you if you go. You’re only bones, who’s gonna miss you if you go. There’s angels in the snow all throughout this graveyard and every one corresponds to someone who was loved. Will you have your own?

text.headline: Powerwolves
text.text:
Merrimack Valley, MA
Song: No God, Know Peace

David Witkum (vocals), Andrew Smith  (guitar), Nicholas Barbieri (bass), and Matt Brodsky (drums). Recorded, Mixed and Mastered by Ryan Stack at Format Audio on March 27, 2011.

text.headline: Life & Limb
text.text:
Allston, MA
Song: named must your fear be before banish it you can

Life & Limb was Bill, Eddie, Erik, John and Sean. Recorded By Ryan Stack at Format Audio.

text.headline: Paint it Black
text.text:
Philadelphia, PA
Song: Bliss

Josh Agran (guitars), Andy Nelson (bass), Jared  Shavelson (drums) and Dan Yemin (voice). Produced, recorded and mixed by Kurt Ballou at GodCity in Salem, MA. Mastered by David Cheppa. From the “Amnesia” 7". Appears Courtesy of Bridge Nine Records.

Underneath our feet; broken glass and concrete
These kids don't walk alone; they own these city streets
Of course they know that freedom sometimes stings
Halogen halos, two wheels for wings
Cranes loom like gallows overhead
And the setting sun paints the sky blood red
But outside it's exactly how I want it to be
We're finally free
The squeal of brakes and the last strains
Of "That's How I Escaped My Certain Fate."
These are the sounds that keep our mothers up late

text.headline: Roadrage
text.text:
Connecticut and Massachusetts
Song: North Star

Kat, J.R., Kevin, Sean, and Ryan.  Recorded by Trevor Vaughan.

text.headline: Ten Thirty Nine
text.text:
Boston, MA
Song: Edward Morgan Forster

1039  is Joey, Varsity, Jeff, & S. Rumbles. Written & Performed by 1039.

“I feel like when you lose a close friend, you go through a period of panic. Like you are never going to be able to live the same. In a way that’s true. What I am learning as of late is that any of us could be next. Though the past can’t change. Wasting time thinking about what happened just prevents you from enjoying the future.” — 1039

“We must be willing to let go of the life we have planned, so as to have the life that is waiting for us.” – Edward Morgan Forster

text.headline: Yellowbirddd
text.text:
Los Angeles, CA
Song: Lionize

Music and Lyrics by Liam McCormack. Recorded, Mixed, and Mastered by Ali A. Memarian (Los Angeles, CA). Liam McCormack (vocals, acoustic guitar, bass, foot stomps) & Ali A. Memarian: (banjitar, electric guitar, tambourine, synths, foot stomps).

text.headline: Wrong Body
text.text:
Beverly, MA
Song: Warning! (Signs!)

Wrong Body is Steve Delany, Andy Szymcik, Jonathan Hislop, and Bryan Mastergeorge.

text.headline: Vanna
text.text:
Boston, MA
Song: Every Bridge

Vanna was Davey Muise, Nick Lambert, Evan Phramakis, Shawn Marquis, Chris Campbell. Vanna is on Artery Recordings/Razor & Tie  Entertainment.

“Gordon—We love and miss you more than we can explain and we owe you so much gratitude as a band and people. You should be here with us now, but your words and actions still live on through us everyday. See you on the other side, brother. Onelove.”

text.headline: Valencourt
text.text:
Providence, RI
Song: Mapping Out The Miles

media.credit: I Am Only an Island music video

text.headline: Therefore I Am
text.text:
Boston, MA
Song: Big Blue

Alex Correia (vocals/programming), Jim Creighton (bass), Brian Marquis (guitar/vocals), Travis Alexander (guitar) and Chris Fernades (drums). Recorded by Mike Poorman at Strangeways Studios in Providence, RI. Mixed by Brian McTernan and Mike Poorman at Salad Days Studios in Baltimore, MD. From “The Sound of Human Lives,” released by Equal Vision Records.

“This song was written for and about our dear friend Gordon Riker. RIP brother.”

The day we played I was a mess. I stood like a child tugging on a mother’s dress, asking why as your family and all of our friends walked in with awkward heavy heads all knowing it just hadn’t hit yet. And every time I saw the hands, the  burning candles and the crosses, every time I glanced up at the goodbyes, I  realized I’d sacrifice the world for it. For one minute more with you. So Big Blue can you hear me sing? Big brother are you listening to me when I say I wish I  had one more day? Do you know each day I see you on the Avenue of Arts? Next to that single ribbon in a tree right in front of me. And when I do, I know I’d sacrifice the world for just one minute more with you. Even though I know half  of knowing what you want is knowing what you have to give to get it. I’d sacrifice the world for it.
